alert.note: Alert for Rutland (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 12:38PM EDT until July 12 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Vermont... Otter Creek At Center Rutland affecting Rutland County. For the Otter Creek...including Center Rutland, Middlebury...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Otter Creek at Center Rutland. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...Until the river level falls below 12 feet, many homes and businesses will continue to be affected, specifically along Dorr Drive and Park Street, and near the junction of Route 4 and West Proctor Road in Rutland. Widespread inundation of low lying roads from Clarendon downstream to Proctor, and Route 73 west of Brandon will continue, and portions of Route 7 in Rutland County will be threatened by tributaries to Otter Creek. Water will recede when the river level falls below 9 feet, with only low lying areas and field flooding remaining until the level drops below 7 feet. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 14.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday was 16.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 5.7 feet Friday morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...The observed maximum river stage of 16.4 feet is the 2nd highest crest in history. The highest crest in history was observed during Tropical Storm Irene where the stage reached 17.21 feet on 8/29/2011. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 200 AM EDT.
